awd_titl_txt: Elucidating chemical features and biological functions of short hydrogen bonds
awd_abstract_narration:
Quantum effects are largely neglected in the description of living organisms, despite their importance in a wide variety of biological processes. Hydrogen bonds are best recognized as interactions that help fold DNA, RNA, and proteins into their functional shapes. Hydrogen bonds that bring atoms together to very short distances show prominent quantum mechanical properties and are closely associated with biological functions that range from enzymatic catalysis to antibiotic resistance. With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Lu Wang from Rutgers University to computationally elucidate the quantum nature and biological functions of short hydrogen bonds (SHBs) in proteins. This project utilizes first principles calculations and simulations (based on the concepts of atomic nuclei and electrons) to unravel the quantum fluctuations and biological roles of SHBs in proteins that signal changes in a cell or that catalyze chemical reactions. Results from these studies provide guiding principles to the design of novel proteins and bio-inspired materials with enhanced functions. This project also enables graduate and undergraduate students, particularly women and students from underrepresented minority groups, to learn advanced computational methods and to discover the essential roles of quantum effects in biological systems.

This research project examines how the interplay of chemical features and quantum effects determines the biological functions of SHBs. The structural and chemical factors that facilitate the formation of SHBs are uncovered by statistically analyzing the Protein Data Bank. The impact of electronic and nuclear quantum effects on the proton behavior, spectroscopic shifts and functional roles of SHBs are studied by first principles simulations, with particular emphasis on the biological processes of bacterial phototaxis and enzyme catalysis. Information from this study helps establish a structure-property relation that explains and predicts the functions of biological SHBs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Hydrogen bonds are essential for many chemical and biological processes.  Although these inter-atomic interactions are fundamentally governed by quantum mechanics, they are usually described as simple electrostatic attractions in studies of biological macromolecules. Our project focuses on short hydrogen bonds, where the donor and acceptor atoms are between 2.3 and 2.7 angstrom apart. We have integrated structural bioinformatics, machine learning and advanced simulation techniques to elucidate the chemical features, quantum effects and biological functions of these short hydrogen bonds in proteins.

By analyzing the top 1% of the highest-quality structures in the Proteins Data Bank, we reveal that short hydrogen bonds are prevalent in proteins, protein-ligand complexes and nucleic acids. Based on the structural, chemical and sequence features we identify, we have developed two machine-learning models, MAPSHB and MAPSHB-Ligand, that effectively predict the formation of short hydrogen bonds in proteins. These models are available on our group's website and through Colab notebooks, which are publicly accessible to all researchers. Users can upload a protein structure and obtain predictions about where short hydrogen bonds are likely to occur in the biomolecule.

We have then explored how quantum fluctuations in short hydrogen bonds impact two important biological processes: bacterial phototaxis in the photoactive yellow protein and the catalytic activity of the enzyme chymotrypsin. Using advanced simulations that incorporate the quantum mechanical nature of both electrons and nuclei, we find significant proton delocalization in the short hydrogen bonds at the active site of both proteins. This quantum delocalization leads to sharing of negative charges within the hydrophobic core of the proteins and causes unusually large 1H NMR chemical shifts. Our mutation calculations suggest that this quantum delocalization helps stabilize the ground signaling state of the photoactive yellow protein and enhances the ability of chymotrypsin to catalyze chemical reactions.

During our project, we discover that short hydrogen bonds are commonly found not only in biological macromolecules but also in liquid systems that are crucial for biological processes. This includes liquid water, solutions with dissolved ions and mixtures of organic molecules. In all cases, quantum fluctuations allow electrons and protons to delocalize in short hydrogen bonds, giving rise to unique properties in these systems. Our findings highlight the importance of quantum effects in understanding hydrogen bonding interactions, particularly in the context of life processes.

This project has provided both graduate and undergraduate students a great opportunity to collaborate and explore how quantum effects impact biological processes. Through this research experience, they have uncovered the quantum properties of hydrogen bonds, gained expertise in quantum chemistry calculations and advanced molecular simulations, and shared their findings with the Rutgers community and at national scientific meetings. This training equips them to become the next generation of scientists in STEM fields.
